title: Erica Jong webchat â as it happened | Books | The Guardian
summary: 'the great thing about getting older is that you no longer worry about decrepitude '
'flying is pretty safe it 's love that 's dangerous '
erica jong is with us now !
post your questions for erica jong .

documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: thanks to everyone who posted questions , and to erica for her answers .
until next time !
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:14pm thanks for your questions , and for your passion .
i still believe that books can change the world , and that my job is to communicate as honestly and humorously as possible .
c1airea asks : one serious question : can you say more about what you mean by we 've only had one third of a feminist revolution ?

one frivolous one : would isadora wing still aspire to ziplessness today guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:14pm until women are represented in politics according to their numbers in the population , we do not have a feminist revolution .
women in politics are still a minority , women rulers of corporations are few and far between .
we do not have complete equality between the genders in power or politics .
i will be very curious to see the world when that has changed , but i probably wo n't be here .

zoe royal asks : do you think a generation of children were negatively affected by debeauvoius , greer and jong when their impressionable mothers craved the unattainable and despised all aspects of domesticity ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:11pm most of the women you mention did not despise all aspects of domesticity - nor do i .
books do n't ruin children 's lives .
not enough people read books to have the effect you describe .
if anything , books open minds and promote choice .
aceparker asks : i wonder if you might tell us your story of how you became a writer .
any life lessons on becoming the best writer you felt you could be ?
who else was critical to success/constructive feedback ?
literary agent , editor , life partner ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:09pm i was lucky to have some writers in my life who encouraged me and criticised my work lovingly .
some of them were poets : robert pack , mark strand , stanley kunitz .
novelists : henry miller , john updike and others .
early on i had a terrific editor called aaron asher who published my first two books of poetry , rejected my first novel which was written from a male point of view .
he wanted me to write a novel from the point of view of the voice in my poems - that novel became fear of flying .
bless him .
id6654445 asks : hi erica , what do you think of feminism now have women become more fearless ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:06pm the opportunities for women have expanded , but they have not expanded enough .
america still has not had a woman president .
let 's go !
quidam86 asks : a lot of online dating profiles will include caveats of no casual hookups , implicating interest in serious or committed sustained relationships only .

do you think that the notions of these this-or-that ultimatums are having an adverse affect on how people approach dating , and if so , what attitudes might you propound to redress the restrictions that people are putting on themselves and others ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:06pm i think most people when they develop some maturity want relationships with human beings .
i 'm reluctant to comment on hookup sites because my experience of them is limited .
the people i know would rather have sex with a person that a computer .
roding asks : why do you think sexual double standards remain so ingrained ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:03pm it comes as no surprise to me that after centuries of oppression , men are treated differently from women in their sexual lives .
but i think things can change .
in fact , that 's why i write .
tommy haze asks : just wanted to ask : why do feminists hate men ?
is it jealousy of our achievements or simply a propaganda tool to keep feminism in the public domain ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:02pm where did you get the idea that feminists hate men ?
do you believe every silly tabloid you read ?

qqqqqqmn asks : how do you understand modern mainstream pornography , i 'm a child of the 70 's when the vagina was a mysterious place , a respectable place , however with what appears to me to be a ubiquitous modern hypersexuality , as an american it seems like lots of american women are fighting to get their vagina 's on the world wide web , sophia loren recently said that rampant internet pornography is ruining men , how do you see this 24/7 explicit internet pornography ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:56pm probably adolescent young men are the main target for pornography .
they 're very curious and very horny .
i do n't think we should judge them too harshly .
when your hormones are in flux , there are many things you want to see on the internet .
and believe me , it 's there .
but as life goes on , i think one becomes less interested in this stuff .
people want real relationships .
i imagine that the sort of men who think masturbating to the internet is better than a real woman have many other psychological problems .
maybe we should send them to doctors rather than the internet .
most men probably outgrow this phase .
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 2:01pm people always want to see social catastrophe in new technological inventions - maybe they 're just not that important .
in my experience most young men prefer girls to the internet , and eventually discover that .
i 'm always surprised by people who want to pass laws against the internet , the cellphone , the fax machine , for fear they will bring down western civilisation .
perhaps we should spend our time working on more important issues , like the pandemic of violence against women .
we see women being kidnapped , raped over and over again in war .
i think all of this went on before the internet .
blaming these things on technology may well be a dodge from looking at them honestly .
i really do think that .
we have to understand the psychology of men who abuse women - it 's too easy to blame it on new inventions .
andrew biswell asks : anthony burgess was your friend and neighbour .
how do you remember him ?
how important was he as an influence on your writing ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:51pm he was my friend , not my neighbour .
we were brought together by our translators , georges belmonde and hortense chabrer .
i thought burgess was a brilliant writer who also was a composer and wrote music every day .
he was an amazing scribomaniac .
he was always writing , either music or literature .
he absolutely was not happy unless he was writing .
he was extremely kind to me as a mentor , and loved my books as i loved his .
so it was a mutually nurturing relationship .

he greatly encouraged me when i was writing fanny , being the true history of fanny hackabout-jones - he had written a brilliant novel about shakespeare , nothing like the sun , which is a kind of model of the historical novel .
he tries to imagine shakespeare 's life as he was writing the sonnets , and he invents or intuits a rivalry between a male and female lover .
he uses the sonnets as a way of talking about shakespeare 's sexuality .
as we know , the elizabethans experimented with male love affairs and burgess tried to understand the psychology of the elizabethans .
he inspired me in the way he understood the historical novel .
though he 's most known for clockwork orange , because of the movie , i much prefer his novel about shakespeare .
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:52pm burgess also wrote several excellent books about shakespeare .
ibenfromdenmark asks : i am often wondering : what is the price for being a writer ?
an artist ?
a celebrity ?

it hasbeen described all over literature and arts , as sympathy for the devil , leaving family behind , being half-a-person , a split personality , the like of a god , loosing your saneity or others¦ was has your price been what is your thought on this ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:44pm being a writer is hard work , and the hardest part of it is you 're working all alone , and nobody is applauding at the end of a paragraph .
you have to be very self-motivated , and willing to rewrite endlessly , because life is pretty chaotic and to make a story out of it requires discipline .
i believe you have to write the truth out of your own heart , but that does not mean everything is literally something you experience .
many people think women have no imaginations , and can only write exactly what they experience .
being a celebrity is a completely different gig .
the kardashian family exemplify this .
mostly it 's about getting free designer clothes for talking about how hard it is to get pregnant , or why you did a sex tape in your youth .
reality tv has impacted all our ideas of fame , so now we are all supposed to be kardashians .
writers are n't real celebrities in my opinion - when a book comes out , for a limited period of time people recognise you at the train station , and mostly in my life it 's been nice .
people come up and say : `` i love your books !
goodbye . ''
that 's the kind of celebrity a writer has .
it 's nothing like being daniel craig , or jennifer lawrence .
these people can literally not cross the street , and i feel great empathy for them .
kungfulil asks : what are your thoughts on the fifty shades of gray books ?
and why do you think they are so successful ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:35pm why do people keep asking me about that abysmal drivel !
sometimes i think the people who ask me about it have never read either my books or james 's books .
they have really nothing in common .
maybe it 's successful because nobody read the story of o , or justine and juliette by the marquis de sade .
fifty shades is a cinderella story about a woman who promises submission in exchange for money .
this is not new .
we might say that women have been doing that for ages , but it does n't turn me on .
i think there 's a great innocence about pornography .

i think a lot of people have never read some of the great pornography , like memoirs of a woman of pleasure by john cleeland , who was an 18th-century writer who impersonated a happy , jolly prostitute .
now , i do n't think there were many happy jolly prostitutes in the 18th century .
i think most of them were gin-soaked and ill , probably with many venereal diseases .
look at hogarth 's etchings .
but the myth of the happy prostitute seems to have lingered .
it 's a case of trying to prove to people that women are happy in oppression .
newsflash : they are n't .
pornography is a form of mythology - it should be taken with a pinch of salt .
men want to believe that women are happy being receptacles - we are n't .
it 's a mythology , it 's male wish fulfilment .
probably as women get freer and freer that kind of pornography will disappear .

wolves didit asks : dear erica , firstly i love your books and found their espousal of liberation very helpful as a young repressed northern irish girl : ) secondly , how do you feel your love of 18th century literature impacts on your de of the feminist heroes in your modern novels ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:29pm thank you for loving my books .
i still believe that books can inspire people to live their lives with more freedom .
most of us find change very hard , and books do inspire change .
18th century literature means a lot to me because it comes from a period when europeans were discovering the rights of man , and of woman .
it 's also a time of satire and i love satire , so maybe my study of the 18th century inspired the humour and satire in my books .

the romans used to say that the satirists lash the world to bring it to its senses , and i do believe that remains true , that if you can be deeply funny , you can wake people up from their indifference .
and it 's a great tool for waking up the reader .
i think one of the first writers i loved was oscar wilde was because of his satire , and george bernard shaw , so i 've always been drawn to that .

documents.title: 'the great thing about getting older is that you no longer worry about decrepitude '
text: pooka macphellimey asks : surely old age is the real fear , as death 's blessing is zero awareness ?
given the inevitability of decrepitude , should the authentic choice of a character who likes to keep it real , be increasing desperation or philosophical surrender ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:25pm the great thing about getting older is that you no longer worry about decrepitude .
also , as your vision gets worse , it 's harder to see yourself in the mirror .
i do think that some people die more gracefully than others .
my own mother who was 101 seemed quite ready to depart ; my father who was 93 raged against the dying of the light .
maybe this is the choice .
dylan thomas writes that to his father , rage against the dying of the light - there 's just different ways that people approach it .
i 've seen a lot of people age gracefully , and really feel that they 'd done what they needed to do in their lives .
it 's quite inspiring when you see that but not everyone can do that .

because my heroine is an actress , she knows as most people in the theatre know , that her appearance is all important to her getting work , so not everybody has that obsession - it really has to do with the profession you 're in .
if you 're a computer programmer nobody cares what you look like .
if you 're in the public eye , you have to do a certain amount of cleaning up i would say to my assistant when i leave the house : now i have to impersonate a famous author .

documents.title: 'flying is pretty safe it 's love that 's dangerous '
text: simonbarsinister asks : i 'm booked on a transatlantic flight and , if i 'm honest , i 'm pretty nervous about it .
any tips ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:21pm flying is pretty safe - it 's love that 's dangerous .

documents.title: 'i have never been on tinder '
text: clareyesno asks : what do you make of tinder ?
more broadly , can sex ever really be no strings attached ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:20pm i have never been on tinder .
friends have talked to me about it , and said that they tried to find lovers on there , but i swear to god , i ca n't remember what they said .

i think when you 're very young you get excited about new technologies and you think they 'll change the world , and then you try them , and i 'm very dubious that new technologies will change the world .
it seems to be if you 're 15 , you might say oooh tinder !
how great !
but if you 're a little older than that , perhaps not .
also , everybody is asking these questions about approving or disapproving - maybe this judgemental thing is the worst thing we 've done with the internet .
we 're supposed to take a political position on these apps , that probably wo n't exist tomorrow .
they 're not here forever .
they 're not like the himalayas .
apps go in , and apps go out .
if you read my book , you realise that the online dating stuff in my book is hilarious satire - no-one could read that book and think that i think that online dating is the solution to our problems .
my heroine meets a selection of fetishists , and fools , who are quite disappointing .
i would say it depends on the person , regarding no strings attached sex .
usually the people i like are interested in human interaction more than the old in-out .
jamesc23 asks : how does it feel to be name-checked in a bob dylan song ?
( highlands ) and do you think bob 's a feminist ?
guardian contributor ericajong 27 october 2015 1:15pm it 's great to be namechecked in a bob dylan song .
do i think he 's a feminist - i 've absolutely no idea , i 've never met him .
i was pleased , i love music , and music has always been very important so i was happy to be mentioned .
did it change my life ?
i do n't think so .
he 's a great talent .
once , when i was on a book tour i saw an exhibition of his paintings and i was very impressed - often , multiple talents go together .

documents.title: erica jong is with us now !
text: beaumont-thomas let 's get this started .

documents.title: post your questions for erica jong
text: published in 1973 , erica jong 's fear of flying was a sensation : a book about a woman who longs for sex that is n't freighted with motherhood or power games , but which is a satisfying even meaningless experience for both men and women .

she coined the popular term zipless fuck to describe this uncomplicated kind of sex , and the book 's liberated but complex heroine , isadora wing , was embraced by feminists ; it sold 27m copies worldwide .
jong revisited wing twice more , and she appears again in her new novel , fear of dying .
times have changed ( there 's an adultery website , zipless.com ) , but the desires remain the same .

her main protagonist is now vanessa wonderman , a 60-year-old actor refusing to let go of her sexual appetite , and having plastic surgery to keep herself in the game it lays bare our prejudices about ageing , and anxieties about death .
with the book out this month , erica is joining us to answer your questions about it and anything else in her career , in a live webchat .
it starts from 1pm bst onwards on tuesday 27 october post your questions for her in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The feminist writer has published a new novel, Fear of Dying, joined us for a live webchat catch up with her answers on Tinder, pornography, Bob Dylan, ageing and Fifty Shades.
